h4.a: CMCSS Schools Closed for the Rest of the 2019-2020 School Year

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/3.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: This page provides guidance on Continued Learning Resources available during the closure due to COVID-19. Children thrive within structured environments, and it will be important to provide opportunities during the day for your children to be creative, read and discuss what they are reading, and participate in physical activity. It is a good idea to create a daily structure in... READ MORE

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: Over the past few weeks, a Communicable Disease Team (CDT) comprised of leaders from CMCSS and the Montgomery County Health Department have been meeting regularly to review the latest guidance from the CDC, monitor the health and attendance of CMCSS students and employees, and make recommendations to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 and other communicable diseases. READ MORE

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: Effective Monday, March 23 until further notice, meals for children will be served Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 10 a.m. to noon at the following locations: Barkers Mill Elementary, Barksdale Elementary, Burt Elementary, Byrns Darden Elementary, Cumberland Heights Elementary, Glenellen Elementary, Kenwood Elementary, Minglewood Elementary, Moore Elementary, Norman Smith Elementary, Ringgold Elementary, and Woodlawn Elementary and Kenwood High, Montgomery Central... READ MORE

p.span:
Since the April 2020 School Board meeting had to be conducted online, the Points of Pride recipients will receive their award certificates in the mail.
The recipients include:
The JROTC Academic Team from Montgomery Central High School was selected to compete at the 2020 U.S. Army JROTC Academic Bowl Championship in Washington DC originally scheduled for June and unfortunately canceled. These Cadets earned top scores out of the 1,490 JROTC teams that competed from around the world. Montgomery Central’s JROTC Academic Team is one of only 32 Army JROTC teams in the nation to advance to the final competition, which includes an all-expense paid trip to the Championship event in D.C.
During the two fast-paced preliminary rounds, students were tested on their knowledge of English, Math, and Science and the JROTC curriculum. One of the main goals of the JROTC Academic Bowl is to prepare students for state exit/graduation exams as well as college entrance exams, such as the SAT. The winner of the U.S. Army JROTC Academic Championship will compete against the winners of the U.S. Air Force, Marine Corps, and Navy JROTC Academic Bowls in the JROTC Joint Service Academic Bowl Championship.
The Montgomery Central High School JROTC Academic Team coached by COL Vernon Lightner includes the following cadets: C/CPT Cheyenne Douthitt; C/SSG Christian Chesser; C/2LT Julia Easter; C/1LT Abria Peoples; C/2LT Aidan Sartor (Alt).
Montgomery Central High senior Vivian Hurn was selected as a State of Tennessee Distinguished Finalist for the Prudential Spirit of Community Awards, one of six in the state. She organized a blood drive at MCHS that collected nearly 80 units of blood from 105 donors. Her efforts included coordinating with the Red Cross, recruiting volunteers, creating a volunteer schedule, making posters and registering donors. She was inspired to focus on this initiative by her mother who has encouraged her to donate blood because of their universal blood types.
Vivian also was named to the Middle Tennessee Wrestling Coaches Association Women’s Dream Team. She earned first place in the Girls 150.
During the first 9 weeks of the school year, several 7th and 8th grade members of the Kenwood Middle School Choir took part in auditions for the Middle Tennessee Honor Choir.
The Middle TN Honor Choir is a very difficult and competitive audition with close to 500 of the best middle school choir students from Clarksville, Nashville, Franklin, and Murfreesboro auditioning and only 100 of the best are chosen to be in the Honor Choir.
Of the students who auditioned from KMS, five students had high enough audition scores to qualify. They include: sopranos Faith Graham, Desirae Weston and Samantha Strysick; alto Blaize Durham; and bass Jaevontae Clemmons, who scored high enough to be the third highest ranked bass in Middle Tennessee. Those students took part in a special concert in Nashville in January. Robert Neumeyer is the choir director at KMS.

img.alt:
Since the April 2020 School Board meeting had to be conducted online, the Points of Pride recipients will receive their award certificates in the mail.
The recipients include:
The JROTC Academic Team from Montgomery Central High School was selected to compete at the 2020 U.S. Army JROTC Academic Bowl Championship in Washington DC originally scheduled for June and unfortunately canceled. These Cadets earned top scores out of the 1,490 JROTC teams that competed from around the world. Montgomery Central’s JROTC Academic Team is one of only 32 Army JROTC teams in the nation to advance to the final competition, which includes an all-expense paid trip to the Championship event in D.C.
During the two fast-paced preliminary rounds, students were tested on their knowledge of English, Math, and Science and the JROTC curriculum. One of the main goals of the JROTC Academic Bowl is to prepare students for state exit/graduation exams as well as college entrance exams, such as the SAT. The winner of the U.S. Army JROTC Academic Championship will compete against the winners of the U.S. Air Force, Marine Corps, and Navy JROTC Academic Bowls in the JROTC Joint Service Academic Bowl Championship.
The Montgomery Central High School JROTC Academic Team coached by COL Vernon Lightner includes the following cadets: C/CPT Cheyenne Douthitt; C/SSG Christian Chesser; C/2LT Julia Easter; C/1LT Abria Peoples; C/2LT Aidan Sartor (Alt).
Montgomery Central High senior Vivian Hurn was selected as a State of Tennessee Distinguished Finalist for the Prudential Spirit of Community Awards, one of six in the state. She organized a blood drive at MCHS that collected nearly 80 units of blood from 105 donors. Her efforts included coordinating with the Red Cross, recruiting volunteers, creating a volunteer schedule, making posters and registering donors. She was inspired to focus on this initiative by her mother who has encouraged her to donate blood because of their universal blood types.
Vivian also was named to the Middle Tennessee Wrestling Coaches Association Women’s Dream Team. She earned first place in the Girls 150.
During the first 9 weeks of the school year, several 7th and 8th grade members of the Kenwood Middle School Choir took part in auditions for the Middle Tennessee Honor Choir.
The Middle TN Honor Choir is a very difficult and competitive audition with close to 500 of the best middle school choir students from Clarksville, Nashville, Franklin, and Murfreesboro auditioning and only 100 of the best are chosen to be in the Honor Choir.
Of the students who auditioned from KMS, five students had high enough audition scores to qualify. They include: sopranos Faith Graham, Desirae Weston and Samantha Strysick; alto Blaize Durham; and bass Jaevontae Clemmons, who scored high enough to be the third highest ranked bass in Middle Tennessee. Those students took part in a special concert in Nashville in January. Robert Neumeyer is the choir director at KMS.

p.span:
Good Afternoon CMCSS Students,
Your teachers and school staff would like to take a moment each day to say hello and encourage you. Check back with us each weekday to see the faces we know you have been missing. They are most certainly missing you!
#cmcss
#schoolsystem
#cmcssmissesyou
#cmcssstrong

p.span:
Good evening,
Thank you for joining us! Tonight’s story, "Ozzie and the Art Contest"
will be read by our friends at the Titans.
youtu.be/bavUqhNRBnA?list=PLzlXK5dEQdXatAjlgp7v8WtMPnw8ORu1r

div.p: The official Instagram account of the Clarksville-Montgomery County School System.

a.span: Dear parents, we appreciate you partnering with us

img.alt: Dear parents, we appreciate you partnering with us to help students stay engaged in their education with the CMCSS Continued Learning Library! If you’d like to share pictures of your children learning at home, please tag them @cmcssinfo #cmcsscontinuedlearning We miss having your children in class, and look forward to seeing all that they are learning from home!!!

a.span: While it takes over 5,000 people with various tale

img.alt: While it takes over 5,000 people with various talents and expertise to keep the district operating at high level, we want to give a huge thanks to our nurses, custodians, and Child Nutrition staff who have gone above and beyond to keep our students fed and the entire CMCSS family as safe and healthy as possible during this pandemic. #cmcss #differencemakers

a.span: It is Read Across America Week! CHS Spanish 3 & 4

img.alt: It is Read Across America Week! CHS Spanish 3 & 4 students visited Barksdale today to read to their 1st grade Spanish Immersion students, with whom they have been pen pals this year. We want to see your CMCSS Read Across America Week photos! Tag them with @cmcssinfo so we can share them throughout the day. #cmcss #readacrossamerica #cmcssreadacrossamerica #readacrossamericaweek #spanishimmersion #BES #CHS #drseussweek

a.span: March is Youth Art Month. CMCSS students celebrate

img.alt: March is Youth Art Month. CMCSS students celebrate by showcasing their masterpieces at the Montgomery County Library. #cmcss #youthartmonth #SES

a.span: Four years ago, Kimberly Bellamy began bringing go

img.alt: Four years ago, Kimberly Bellamy began bringing golden retrievers registered with Pet Partners animal therapy program to classrooms in CMCSS. With the three dogs combined, Mrs. Bellamy has visited CMCSS schools 140 times, which amounts to over 200 hours. They have visited 14 elementary schools, 2 middle schools, 2 high schools; in addition to the Synergy Program and the Learning Center. Visits have been related to "animals in the community" lessons, behavior incentives, and socialization for CDC students as well. But the majority of visits are to strengthen reading confidence using the student-animal bond. There is no judgment from a dog. Charlie, Skiff and Penny are their names. The Bellamy dogs are registered with the Pet Partners animal therapy program, and each have to pass the evaluation every two years. Significant training goes in to preparing for the test, but more importantly, the animal has to have the temperament to be a therapy dog. They have to enjoy meeting new people and have excellent manners in public. Charlie and Skiff have almost equal number of visits. Penny has just 18 visits with CMCSS. Richview Middle School teacher Michelle Main and West Creek Elementary School teacher Karma Sherk have consistently invited Mrs. Bellamy to their classrooms on a monthly basis, year after year. They have seen what an effect it has on their students and have been so committed to participating. #cmcss #wces #Charlie #therapydogs

a.span: Students from the Academy of Teaching and Learning

img.alt: Students from the Academy of Teaching and Learning at WCHS work with students at WCES on a weekly basis. #cmcss #elementaryschool #highschool #academy #WCHS #WCES

p.br: Due to Instagram platform changes on March 31, 2020, this Instagram account needs to be reconnected to allow the feed to continue updating. Reconnect on plugin Settings page
